column1: law” confirms that enrolment as an Attorney-at-Law is a privilege that is conferred on a
person by the Supreme Court and that it is the responsibility of such person to continue
to maintain such reputation and conduct at  all times in order to enjoy the privilege of
being  an  Attorney-at-Law.  The  repercussions  of  failing  to  do  so  are  clearly  set  out  in
Section 42 (2) of the Act which provides that, “Every person admitted and enrolled as an
Attorney-at-Law who shall be guilty of any deceit, malpractice, crime, or offence may be
suspended from practice or removed from office by any three Judges of the Supreme Court
